reflection: Here again Jesus offers hope. The Holy Spirit gives us the strength to endure the unreasonable hatred and evil in our world and the hostility many have toward Christ. ~ This is especially comforting for those facing persecution. Jesus uses two names for the Holy Spirit ~ "Counselor" and "Spirit of Truth." The word Counselor stands for the encouraging, and strengthening work of the Spirit. Spirit of Truth points to the teaching, illuminating, and reminding work of the Spirit. The Holy Spirit ministers to both the head and the heart, both dimensions are important. God wants us to know that we are not alone. You have the Holy Spirit to comfort you, to teach you the truth, and help you.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Seeing their faith, Jesus said to the paralyzed man, "My son, your sins are forgiven." (Mk. 2:5)
reflection: Before saying to the man, "Get up, " Jesus said, "Your sins are forgiven." To the Jewish leaders this statement was blasphemous, claiming to do something only God could do. According to the law, the punishment for this sin was death. (Lev. 24:15, 16). The Jewish leaders understood correctly that Jesus was claiming a divine position, but their judgment of Him was wrong. Jesus was not blaspheming because His claim was true. Jesus is God, and He proved it by healing the paralyzed man. (Mk. 2:9-12). So as we pray for those for whom the doctor says, "There is no hope." Let us pray, "We commend this brother/sister into Your care and keeping." For there is always hope in the Lord. (Mk. 5:35, 36)
prayer: Dear Lord, our Divine Physician, dispense the medicine of Your forgiveness and heal my heart every day. Amen.

reflection: This "manna that has been hidden away in Heaven" suggests the spiritual nourishment that the faithful believers will receive, As the believers traveled toward the Promised Land. They are the evidence that a person has been accepted by God and declared worthy to receive eternal life.
prayer: Dear Lord and Savior, feed me. Assure me of God's "Not guilty" verdict as only you can. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: And the blood of Jesus, His Son, purifies us from all sin. (I Jn. 1:7)
reflection: In our verse, John writes about the dirt of sin, the grime of daily life that is ground into our souls. He speaks about the mud of sinful birth and sinful life that soils everyone, making us fit only for hell. BUT then he also points us to the only detergent that can wash sin's stain completely out of our souls. That's the precious blood of Jesus, God's Son. His blood doesn't just brush off sin's outward stain but removes it completely. It doesn't leave any ugly residue but lifts it out totally. How is this possible? It is because that blood comes from the veins of Him who is not only man but God from all eternity. God who promised forgiveness is faithful. At Calvary's cross we see that He did not merely sweep sin under the carpet but demanded full payment from His Son as our substitute. That Son's suffering and death is the miracle whitener that cleanses even the most corrupt sinner and the most crimson stain.
prayer: Dear Lord, thank You that I can say, "Grace and life eternal in that blood I find; Blest be His compassion, infinitely kind." Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: God has given us eternal life, and this life is in His Son. (I Jn. 5:11)
reflection: "God has given us eternal life, " John writes. Life with God is not something we can earn. It's not payment for our deeds, or a prize we deserve. Only one word fits ~ gift. Only one could give this gift ~ God. He looked down on us, born dead in unbelief, bound for eternal death in hell's dungeon, and had pity on is. With amazing love He prepared for us a life that never ends. This life is in His Son, nowhere else can we find life with God but in His Son. Only God's Son could fill the cross, feel hell's pangs, fling open death's grave, and make it count for us. The price for life with God was so steep that only God Himself could handle it.
prayer: Dear Lord, thank You for the life that brings me joy on earth and eternity at Your side. Amen.

It's not payment for our deeds, or a prize we deserve. Only one word fits ~ gift. Only one
could give this gift ~ God. He looked down on us, born dead in unbelief, bound for eternal
death in hell's dungeon, and had pity on is. With amazing love He prepared for us a life that 
never ends...

This life is in His Son, nowhere else can we find life with God but in His Son. Only God's
Son could fill the cross, feel hell's pangs, fling open death's grave, and make it count for
us. The price for life with God was so steep that only God Himself could handle it...

Prayer Suggestion:
Dear Lord, thank You for the life that brings me joy
on earth and eternity at Your side...Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: It is a trustworthy statement, deserving full acceptance, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners, among whom I am foremost of all. (I Tim. 1:15)
reflection: If I were to write the story of my life, I would have to start as Paul did ~ making a full confession, "I am the worst of sinners." Such a confession is not easy to make. How is it that everything else we like to exaggerate, but our sins we like to shrink? Other people's sins we can easily spot, but our own somehow escape detection. But the plain truth remains that we are all sinners. And I'll be the first to confess that I don't need a microscope to examine my daily life. Sin's contamination is clearly visible. Thank God for the fact that, "Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners." Because of Him God won't write the word lost over my grave, but saved by His grace in Christ Jesus. Because of this no more needs to be said in the story of my life.
prayer: Dear Lord, let it be said of me that "Chief of sinners though I be, Jesus shed His blood of me." Amen.

verse: For I live in eager expectation and hope that I will never do anything that causes me shame, but that I will always be bold for Christ, as I have been in the past, and that my life will always honor Christ, whether I live or die. (Phil. 1:20)
reflection: To have Christ and to work for Christ ~ that's what life is all about. ~ Right? ~ Of course! But will everyone nod their heads approvingly if we add that in life believers are called upon to suffer for Christ? Paul would. As of yet in our country there's no danger of losing our heads because of our faith. But our problem to often is that we hide our heads because of our faith, when all around us people are foolishly saying that truth is what you want to believe. It takes Christian fortitude to preach that only what God's Word says is true. When matters like morals, marriage, and life's meaning flip-flop every other day, it requires strong faith to stand up for what God has said in His unchanging Word. Remember Those who rely on God's free grace in Christ Jesus, God's power to take care of their lives, and God's wisdom to lead correctly will along with Paul, have what it takes to suffer for Christ.
prayer: Dear Lord, I am weak, but You are strong, be with me. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: And the Word became flesh, and dwelt among us, and we beheld His glory, glory as of the only begotten from the Father, full of grace and truth. (Jn. 1:14)
reflection: When Jesus was born, God became a man. He was not part man and part God; He was completely human and completely divine (Col. 2:9). Before Christ came, people could know God partially. After Christ came, people could know God fully because He became visible and tangible in Christ. Christ is the perfect expression of God in human form. The two most common errors people make about Jesus are to minimize His humanity or to minimize His divinity. Remember Jesus is both God and man.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: As for me and my household, we will serve the Lord. (Jos. 24:15)
reflection: Remember the promises we made at our weddings? In this month when many marriages occur, we might do well to review those promises. Even more so, we might want to look at the promises behind successful and enduring marriages. BUT this text wants us to examine how it has gone with our promise to serve the Lord. Unless the Lord in His grace reminds us what He has done for us, we can't even begin to serve Him. When sin bends our spirits in marriage, how can we turn to Him for relief unless we know Him to be the Lord who assures us, "Take heart, . your sins are forgiven" (Mt. 9:2)? Before we can serve the Lord in our marriage, we need to remember what He has done for us. The secret to serving the Lord is to let Him serve us. When His Word dwells in our homes richly, His pardon in Christ Jesus will cheer our hearts and empower our lives. Joyful service to Him will follow. So will remembering and renewing the promises we made to each other on our wedding days.
prayer: Dear Lord, I long to walk closer to You. Feed me with Your Word so that I can. Amen.

Before we can serve the Lord in our marriage, we need to remember what He has done for us...

The secret to serving the Lord is to let Him serve us. When His Word dwells in our homes richly,
His pardon in Christ Jesus will cheer our hearts and empower our lives. Joyful service to Him will
follow. So will remembering and renewing the promises we made to each other on our wedding days...
